channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Matt Markiewicz on Tradr 2X Long QBTS Daily ETF (QBTX)
item.description: Tradr ETFs Head of Product and Capital Markets Matt Markiewicz discusses the Tradr 2X Long QBTS Daily ETF (ticker: QBTX) in an interview with Scarlet Fu and Eric Balchunas on “ETF IQ.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Asia Stocks to Gain as Traders Shrug Off Downgrade: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks in Asia were poised to track Wall Street higher as investors looked past the US credit downgrade by Moody’s Ratings.
item.dc:creator: Jason Scott

item.title: CATL Set to Debut in Hong Kong After World’s Top Listing in 2025
item.description: Contemporary Amperex Technology Co. Ltd. will start trading in Hong Kong Tuesday after the Chinese battery giant wrapped up the world’s biggest listing this year, raising HK$35.7 billion ($4.6 billion) despite being blacklisted by the Pentagon and grinding through geopolitical storms.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

media:content.media:description: A cross-section of a CATL battery for electric vehicles. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: GLS CEO on How Tariffs Are Spurring Onshoring Resurgence
item.description: Global Location Strategies President and CEO Didi Caldwell discusses the resurgence of onshoring amid the Trump administration's tariffs on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Moody's US Downgrade Not a Surprise: Stony Brook's Kelton
item.description: Stephanie Kelton, Stony Brook University professor of public policy and economics, discusses the Moody's downgrade of the US sovereign credit rating on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China Pivot, Sweden's Innovation Engine, US Army Secretary Driscoll | Wall Street Week
item.description: This week, former US Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and Hoover Institution's Elizabeth Economy discuss the US pivot on trade dealings with China. Plus, a look at Sweden’s vibrant capital markets and Nasdaq's role in its innovation ecosystem. Later, US Army Secretary Driscoll joins us with the administration's approach to a decades-long spending challenge at the Pentagon. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Vanke Bond’s 144% Rally Shows Credit Strain Easing After Rescue
item.description: Financial strains are easing at China Vanke Co. after its largest state shareholder threw a lifeline to the company that proved too big to fail.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Emma Dong

media:content.media:description: Residential buildings under construction at the China Vanke Co. Isle Maison development in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Jan. 17, 2025. Concerns over China Vanke spiked amid questions on the latest status of its top executive and a local news report that the property developer may be seized by state authorities.

item.title: Coinbase’s Customer Data Theft Is Being Investigated by DOJ
item.description: The US Justice Department has opened a probe into a recent breach at the leading cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase Global Inc., according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Chris Strohm, Jeff Stone

media:content.media:description: Monitors display Coinbase signage during the company's initial public offering (IPO) at the Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, April 14, 2021. Coinbase Global Inc., the largest U.S. cryptocurrency exchange, is set to debut on Wednesday through a direct listing, an alternative to a traditional initial public offering that has only been deployed a handful of times. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Nippon Steel Boosts Investment for Proposed US Steel Deal
item.description: Nippon Steel Corp. has bolstered its pledge to invest in United States Steel Corp. in the event that President Donald Trump approves the Japanese company’s proposed $14.1 billion takeover, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux

media:content.media:description: The United States Steel Corp. Clairton Coke Works facility in Clairton, Pennsylvania, US, on Monday, Sept. 9, 2024. United States Steel Corp. faces the prospect of being broken apart and sold in parts if Nippon Steel Corp.'s $14.1 billion takeover fails.

item.title: Carrier CEO Gitlin on Data Centers, US Hiring Plans
item.description: Carrier Chair and CEO David Gitlin discusses the company's data center business and plans to invest $1 billion to grow US manufacturing on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Royal Caribbean Sheds Junk-Debt Status After Moody’s Upgrade
item.description: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. regained its investment-grade status on Monday, as Moody’s Ratings matched the upgrade that S&P Global Ratings made three months ago.
item.dc:creator: Caleb Mutua, Redd Brown

media:content.media:description: The Royal Caribbean Wonder of the Seas cruise ship docked in Nassau, Bahamas, on Monday, April 29, 2024. Cruise lines have spent at least $1.5 billion since 2019 to expand or improve private stops in the Caribbean, according to Bloomberg calculations.

item.title: S&P 500 Erases 1% Slide as Dip Buyers Wade Back In: Markets Wrap
item.description: A renewed wave of dip buying fueled a rebound in stocks, with traders looking past the US credit downgrade by Moody’s Ratings that had earlier sent bond yields jumping. The dollar fell.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Emerging FX Jumps as Moody’s Downgrade Undermines the Dollar
item.description: An index for emerging-market currencies advanced on Monday as the greenback fell following Moody’s Ratings downgrade of US government debt, while lawmakers in Washington debated more tax cuts.
item.dc:creator: Maria Elena Vizcaino, Raphael Almeida Dos Santos, Peter Laca, Subhadip Sircar

media:content.media:description: A supporter waves a Romanian flag outside the campaign headquarters of Nicusor Dan. Photographer: Alexandra Corcode/Bloomberg

item.title: Senator Asks SEC to Probe Firms Advising Against JBS Listing
item.description: Kentucky Senator Rand Paul has asked the top US securities regulator to probe two major firms that have advised their clients to vote against a proposed New York listing by JBS SA, the world’s largest meat producer.
item.dc:creator: Gerson Freitas Jr

media:content.media:description: Senator Rand Paul, a Republican from Kentucky and chairman of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, during a confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. Troy Edgar, a Navy veteran and former mayor of Los Alamitos, California, served as DHS’s chief financial officer during Trump’s first term, overseeing the department’s more than $90 billion budget and its workforce. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Sweden as Europe's Bright Spot for Capital Markets
item.description: How has a nation of 10 million people built one of the most dynamic capital markets in Europe? Adena Friedman speaks with us from Stockholm on Nasdaq’s presence in the Nordic country. Sweden's minister for financial markets Niklas Wykman, Investor AB CEO Christian Cederholm, Froda CEO Olle Lundin and Swedbank CEO Jens Henriksson talk about the country's combination of social welfare and business-friendly policies that encourage risk-taking and deepen its capital markets at a time when the rest of the EU struggles to innovate and grow. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Anchors Get Nostalgic as S&P Shakes Off Moody's Cut | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: DC’s Smithsonian Loses Triple-A Rating After US Credit Downgrade
item.description: The Smithsonian Institution, the world’s largest museum complex boasting 21 museums and the National Zoo, has lost its top-tier credit rank from Moody’s Ratings just days after the firm stripped the US government of its last triple-A rating.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rembert

media:content.media:description: A statue of Joseph Henry, the first secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, stands outside the headquarters of the Smithsonian, known as "The Castle," in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Monday, Sept. 8, 2008. The Smithsonian Institution is the world's largest museum complex and research organization with 19 museums and 9 research centers.

item.title: S&P Ends On Cusp of Bull Market as Traders Shrug Off Moody’s Cut
item.description: US stocks closed little changed on Monday after paring a 1% drop while Treasuries gained, following a downgrade from Moody’s Ratings on the US government’s credit score.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.

item.title: Dimon Warns Markets Are Underestimating Geopolitical, Inflation Risks
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. Chief Executive Officer Jamie Dimon warned against complacency in the face of a slew of risks, citing everything from inflation and credit spreads to geopolitics.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Levitt, Yizhu Wang

media:content.media:description: Jamie Dimon, chief executive officer of JPMorgan Chase & Co.

item.title: Anthropic’s Focus on Safety Helped It Rack Up Billions
item.description: Bloomberg’s Shirin Ghaffary discusses how Anthropic has cultivated a reputation for taking safety more seriously than competitor OpenAI. Ghaffary explains what Anthropic must do to maintain that focus while staying competitive, on “Bloomberg Technology” with Ed Ludlow. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Apollo Taps Nearly $1 Billion of Private Debt for PowerGrid Buy
item.description: Apollo Global Management Inc. is turning to private credit to finance its acquisition of electric utility PowerGrid Services from Sterling Group, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Weinman

media:content.media:description: Power transmission towers outside the Crimson Battery Energy Storage Project in Blythe, California, US, on Tuesday, Oct. 18, 2022. Axium Infrastructure and Canadian Solar’s subsidiaries of Recurrent Energy and CSI Energy Storage announced the two have installed and activated what they are calling the world’s largest single-phase energy storage facility. Photographer: Bing Guan/Bloomberg

item.title: US Bonds Swing as Dip Buyers Enter After Moody’s-Fueled Selloff
item.description: Treasuries whipsawed on Monday, with dip buyers stepping in as a selloff brought on by a downgrade of US debt by Moody’s Ratings sent 30-year yields briefly above 5%.
item.dc:creator: Alice Atkins, Naomi Tajitsu

media:content.media:description: The Treasury Department Building, in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. Photographer: Aaron Schwartz/Bloomberg

item.title: Thoma Bravo Nears Deal for Insurance Tech Firm Itel
item.description: Buyout firm Thoma Bravo is in advanced talks to acquire to acquire GTCR-backed Itel, an insurance technology firm focused on property and casualty claims services, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Gould

media:content.media:description: Signage at the Thoma Bravo private equity firm in the Brickell neighborhood of Miami, Florida, US, on Wednesday, March 5, 2025. Since the current iteration of Thoma Bravo was founded in 2008, it's been involved in roughly a fifth of all private equity buyouts in the sector as measured by value, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Photographer: Scott McIntyre/Bloomberg

item.title: Lux Capital Takes on Science Risk
item.description: Years of underinvestment in science are putting the US behind China in technological advances, says Lux Capital Managing Partner Josh Wolfe. Wolfe explains why the firm is lowering the bar for science risk in the ventures it invests in, with Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Greece Asks UK Court to Rule on GDP Warrant Buyback
item.description: Greece is taking a dispute over its GDP warrants to a court in the UK, the latest nation to become embroiled in a battle with holders of the growth-linked debt instruments.
item.dc:creator: Constantine Courcoulas, Jorgelina Do Rosario

item.title: Interest in Middle East AI Startups Grows
item.description: Government investment in data center infrastructure in the Middle East is allowing venture capital firms to focus on application-layer startups in the region. Luca Barbi, general partner and COO at Riyadh-based STV, discusses the firm’s new $100 million AI-focused fund with Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Pony AI Earnings Put Investors on Alert for Robotaxi Expansion
item.description: Pony AI Inc.’s report on its first full quarter as a publicly traded company will have investors and analysts homing in on how a new generation of robotaxis could put the firm on a path to profitability.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Kniazhevich

media:content.media:description: A Pony.ai Inc. autonomous vehicle with the branding of the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) travels along a road in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, July 8, 2021. The conference runs through to July 10.

item.title: Fed’s Bostic on Rate Policy, Tariffs, Framework Review
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic discusses the outlook for interest rates and the economic impact of tariffs. Speaking with Mike McKee on Bloomberg Television, Bostic says he expects one Fed rate cut this year.

item.title: Bond Investors Detect Trouble in US Debt Stripped of AAA Rating
item.description: Even before talk of fresh unfunded tax cuts took center stage in the budget wrangling on Capitol Hill, US bond investors were making their views loud and clear: If the government keeps spending more than it takes in, there will be consequences.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Alice Gledhill

media:content.media:description: Bessent speaks during a House hearing on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. The Treasury secretary acknowledged US debt is on an unsustainable path.

item.title: Carlyle’s AlpInvest Bundles Private Equity Stakes in $1 Billion Financing
item.description: Carlyle Group Inc.’s private equity platform AlpInvest is preparing to sell a roughly $1 billion structured finance instrument backed by cash flows from some of the buyout funds it oversees, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: UKRAINE - 2021/04/23: In this photo illustration, the Carlyle Group logo of a US private equity company is seen on a smartphone and a pc screen. (Photo Illustration by Pavlo Gonchar/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)
